docs.text: Zendikit School Education is an investment in the betterment of the present and future of the human condition. We take no money from you, and in return we confer no degree. We are interested only in growing skills backed by deep understanding. All material is project-based where practical. Participation requires that you are self-directed, have a computer, and have internet access.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Education is an investment in the betterment of the present and future of the human condition. We take no money from you, and in return we confer no degree. We are interested only in growing skills backed by deep understanding. All material is project-based where practical. Participation requires that you are self-directed, have a computer, and have internet access.
docs.title: Zendikit School

docs.text: Introduction The purpose of this catalog is to bootstrap reading ability to expedite consuming Japanese material. This catalog is not exhaustive. There is grammar in the Japanese language not present here. Also, for grammar points presented here, there are nuances not covered. While certification such as that provided by the JLPT is not indicative of language mastery, the various JLPT levels do provide a convenient way to organize practical grammar points. Here we provide a catalog of grammar by approximate JLPT level. Grammar points in each level are presented in alphabetical order . Prerequisites You must know the kana. Also, while we try to use relatively simple vocabulary in the example sentences, you should understand the general-use kanji --if not the readings then at least the meanings to intuit the gist of the example sentences. References We recommend A Dictionary of Basic Japanese Grammar , A Dictionary of Intermediate Japanese Grammar , and A Dictionary of Advanced Japanese Grammar , all by Makino and Tsutsui, as supplements.
docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: The purpose of this catalog is to bootstrap reading ability to expedite consuming Japanese material. This catalog is not exhaustive. There is grammar in the Japanese language not present here. Also, for grammar points presented here, there are nuances not covered. While certification such as that provided by the JLPT is not indicative of language mastery, the various JLPT levels do provide a convenient way to organize practical grammar points. Here we provide a catalog of grammar by approximate JLPT level. Grammar points in each level are presented in alphabetical order .

docs.text: We recommend A Dictionary of Basic Japanese Grammar , A Dictionary of Intermediate Japanese Grammar , and A Dictionary of Advanced Japanese Grammar , all by Makino and Tsutsui, as supplements.

docs.text: N5 Grammar あげる Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を教えて あげます 。 I will teach you Japanese. この本を あげます 。 I'll give you this book. An auxiliary verb indicating that the speaker gives something or some action to someone else. When speaking to someone of lower status, あげるcan be replaced with やる. The honorific form is さしあげる. あとで (後で) Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強した 後で 寝ました。 I slept after studying Japanese. クラスの 後で 帰りました。 I went home after class. A conjunction indicating that something takes place after something else. か Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は英語 か 日本語を勉強します。 I will study either English or Japanese. 明日授業がある か ない か 分かりません。 I don't know whether there is class tomorrow or not. A grammar particle which indicates an alternative. かた (方) Grammar Point Sentence 1 その漢字の書き 方 が分かりません。 I don't know how to write that kanji. A nominalizing suffix indicating a way of doing something. から Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本へ行く から 日本語を勉強する。 I'm studying Japanese because I'm going to Japan next year. 高かった から 買いませんでした。 I didn't buy it because it was expensive. 2 日本語を勉強して から 全部を忘れました。 After studying Japanese, I forgot everything. A conjunction indicating a reason or cause. A conjunction indicating after or since something takes place. くらい Grammar Point Sentence 1 百五十円 くらい でした。 It was about 150 yen. 二時間 くらい かかります。 I takes about 2 hours. A particle indicating an approximate quantity or otherwise translated as "about." ぐらい has the same meaning. くれる Grammar Point Sentence 1 彼は日本語を教えて くれました 。 He taught me Japanese. 彼はこの本を くれました 。 He gave me this book. An auxiliary verb indicating that someone gives something or does some action for someone else. The honorific form is くださる. こんな Grammar Point Sentence 1 こんな 本を買いたいです。 I'd like to buy a book like this . そんな ことしないでよ！ Don't do such a thing ! A word meaning "such a thing" or "this sort of thing." It can be adjusted for proximity to the speaker (そんな、あんな) or be made inquisitive (どんな). こんなに Grammar Point Sentence 1 そんなに 難しかった？ Was it that difficult? こんなに 美味しいこと誰でも好きです。 Anyone likes something delicious like this . A word meaning "like this." It can be adjusted for proximity to the speaker (そんなに、あんなに). さ Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語の難し さ がよく分かってる。 I know the difficulty of Japanese. A nominalizing suffix attachable to the stem of adjectives. しか Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語 しか 勉強しません。 I study only Japanese. A particle indicating that something S and only S is the case, often translated as "nothing," "nobody," or "only." すぐ Grammar Point Sentence 1 朝起きて すぐ に日本語を勉強します。 As soon as I wake up, I study Japanese. 学校は駅の すぐ 前です。 The school is right in front of the station. An adverb indicating not much temporal or physical distance, often translated as "as soon as," "immediately," "right." たい Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は日本語を勉強し たい です。 I want to study Japanese. 私は刺身を食べ たい です。 I want to eat sashimi. An auxiliary adjective indicating the desire to do something. だけ Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語が勉強した だけ です。 I just studied (and did nothing else with) Japanese. 私 だけ 日本語を話せます。 Only I can speak Japanese. A particle expressing a limit on something, often translated as "just," "merely," "only," or "that's all." だろう See でしょう. って Grammar Point Sentence 1 彼女は日本語を勉強する って 言った。 She said she studies Japanese. 私は日本語を勉強しようか って 思います。 I wonder if I should study Japanese. A colloquial particle indicating a quotation. て Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は日本へ行っ て 勉強しました。 I went to Japan and studied. これは高く て 美味しい。 This is expensive and delicious. 彼は先生 で 優しい。 He is a teacher, and he is nice. A verb or i-adjective ending indicating "and." For na-adjectives and nouns, て becomes で instead. で Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本人ははし で 食べます。 Japanese people eat with chopsticks. これは日本語 で 何ですか。 What is this in Japanese? A grammar particle which indicates the use of something for doing something. でしょう Grammar Point Sentence 1 彼は日本語で話す でしょう 。 He will probably speak in Japanese. この本は高い だろう 。 This book is probably expensive. An auxiliary indicating conjecture grounded in no substantial evidence. だろう is the informal form. でも Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語 でも 話せます。 I can even speak Japanese. 子供 でも そのことをできます。 Even a child can do that. A particle meaning "even." と Grammar Point Sentence 1 私はあなた と 日本語を勉強します。 I study Japanese with you. 私は日本人 と 結婚しました。 I (got) married ( to ) a Japanese person. A grammar particle indicating a reciprocal relationship with the subject. どう Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語で どう 言いますか。 How do you say it in Japanese? 本は どう でしたか。 How was the book? A grammar particle which asks about the state of something or someone or the way of doing something. と同じくらい〜 Grammar Point Sentence 1 この本はその本 と同じくらい 面白い。 This book is as interesting as that one. A phrase indicating that one thing is as 〜 as another. とき Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強する 時 本をたくさん読みます。 When I study Japanese I read a lot of books. 静かな 時 勉強できます。 I'm able to study when it's quiet. A dependent noun indicating a time when someone or something did or does something. どちら Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語と英語と、 どちら が面白い？ Between Japanese and English, which is more interesting? A word meaning "which," among a group of things, particularly two. どれ Grammar Point Sentence 1 黄色と紫色と青色で、 どれ が一番美しいですか。 Between yellow, purple, and blue, which is the most beautiful? A word meaning "which," among a group of 3 or more. ないで Grammar Point Sentence 1 勉強し ないで 学校へ来ました。 I came to school without studying. A negative te-form indicating not doing something or without doing something. ながら Grammar Point Sentence 1 本を読み ながら 学校へ歩きました。 I walked to school while reading a book. A conjunction indicating the surrounding clauses happen simultaneously, often translated as "while" or "with." なる Grammar Point Sentence 1 あなたの日本語が上手に なりました 。 You've become good at Japanese. 寒く なりました 。 It's become cold. A word meaning "to become" or "come to be." に Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強（し） に 学校へ行きます。 I'm going to school (in order) to study Japanese. 本を買い に 来ました。 I came (in order) to buy a book. A particle indicating the purpose of movement. This construct is only used with motion verbs like 行く, 来る, 帰る, 入る, and 出る. の Grammar Point Sentence 1 本は日本語 の を買いました。 As for books, I bought a Japanese one . あの本はトム の です。 That book is Tom's book . 2 どうして勉強している の ？ Why are you studying ( you've got to tell me )? 明日テストがある の 。 Because there's a test tomorrow. 3 勉強する の は難しい。 Studying is difficult. 彼が日本語を話す の を聞きました。 I heard him speaking Japanese. A dependent, indefinite pronoun indicating "one" or "_'s." An informal sentence-final particle indicating an explanation or asking for an explanation, used by children or female speakers. If male speakers use it, it is only for questions. A clause nominalizer. のです Grammar Point Sentence 1 何をしている んです か。 What are you doing ( you've got to tell me )? 日本語を勉強している のです 。 ( The explanation is that ) I'm studying Japanese. A sentence-ending phrase indicating an explanation or asking for an explanation. An informal form is んです. ばかり Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語 ばかり 勉強しています。 I'm studying only Japanese. 私は勉強した ばかり です。 I studied and haven't done anything else . A particle indicating that something is the only state, thing, or action. ほう Grammar Point Sentence 1 あなたの本はどっちですか。 Which book is yours? 大きい ほう です。 The bigger one. 好きな ほう を取ってください。 Please take the one you like most . A word indicating more than or greater in a comparison. It comes from the form ほうが〜より. ほうが〜より Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語の ほうが 英語 より 面白い。 Japanese is more interesting than English. 遊ぶ ほうが 勉強する より 楽しい。 Playing is more fun than studying. A phrase for comparing two things, where one is more or greater than the other. ほど Grammar Point Sentence 1 英語は日本語 ほど 面白くない。 English is not as interesting as Japanese. A particle indicating an extent or degree, often translated as "[not] as ~ as ~." まえに (前に) Grammar Point Sentence 1 寝る 前に 日本語を勉強します。 I study Japanese before I sleep. テストの 前に 勉強します。 I'll study before the test. A conjunction indicating in front of or before something occurs. まだ Grammar Point Sentence 1 まだ 日本語を分かりません。 I still don't understand Japanese. 私は まだ 勉強しています。 I'm still studying. An adverb indicating that someone or something is still in a state they were previously in, often translated as "still" or "(not) yet." 〜ましょう Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し ましょう 。 Let's study Japanese. 日本語を勉強し ましょう か。 Shall we study Japanese? A formal volitional verb ending indicating the speaker's intent or invitation to do something. 〜ませんか Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し ませんか 。 Would you like to study Japanese? 2 一緒に勉強し ない？ Wanna study together? The formal negative question form of a verb can be used to extend an invitation formally. The informal non-past negative form of a verb can be used to extend an invitation informally. まで Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は五時 まで 日本語を勉強します。 I will study Japanese until 5 o'clock. 東京 まで 3時間かかります。 It takes 3 hours until Tokyo. A grammar particle which indicates a spacial or temporal limit. もう Grammar Point Sentence 1 もう 日本語を勉強しましたか。 Have you already studied Japanese? もう 本がありません。 I don't have the book anymore . And adverb indicating that someone or something is no longer in a state they were previously in, often translated as "already" or "(not) any longer." もらう Grammar Point Sentence 1 友達はこの本を買って もらいました 。 My friend bought me this book. 友達にこの本を もらいました 。 I received this book from my friend. An auxiliary verb indicating that the speaker or someone else receives something or some benefit from an action from someone else. The honorific form is いただく. よう Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し よう 。 Let's study Japanese. 地球を守 ろう 。 Let's protect the Earth. An informal volition verb ending indicating the speaker's intent or invitation to do something. ようとおもう (ようと思う) Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し ようと思います 。 I think I'll study Japanese. 英語で話す まいと思います 。 I think I won't speak in English. A phrase indicating that the speaker desires to do something. The negative form is まいと思う. られる Grammar Point Sentence 1 漢字を読 める 。 I can read kanji. 刺身を食べ られます 。 I can eat sashimi. An auxiliary verb indicating the potential to do something. を Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は日本語 を 勉強します。 I study Japanese. 2 私は公園 を 歩きました。 I walked through the park. A grammar particle indicating a direct object. A grammar particle indicating a space through or along which someone or something moves.
docs.title: N5

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 朝起きて すぐ に日本語を勉強します。 As soon as I wake up, I study Japanese. 学校は駅の すぐ 前です。 The school is right in front of the station. An adverb indicating not much temporal or physical distance, often translated as "as soon as," "immediately," "right."

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は日本語を勉強し たい です。 I want to study Japanese. 私は刺身を食べ たい です。 I want to eat sashimi. An auxiliary adjective indicating the desire to do something.

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語が勉強した だけ です。 I just studied (and did nothing else with) Japanese. 私 だけ 日本語を話せます。 Only I can speak Japanese. A particle expressing a limit on something, often translated as "just," "merely," "only," or "that's all."

docs.text: See でしょう.

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 彼女は日本語を勉強する って 言った。 She said she studies Japanese. 私は日本語を勉強しようか って 思います。 I wonder if I should study Japanese. A colloquial particle indicating a quotation.

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は日本へ行っ て 勉強しました。 I went to Japan and studied. これは高く て 美味しい。 This is expensive and delicious. 彼は先生 で 優しい。 He is a teacher, and he is nice. A verb or i-adjective ending indicating "and." For na-adjectives and nouns, て becomes で instead.
docs.title: て

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本人ははし で 食べます。 Japanese people eat with chopsticks. これは日本語 で 何ですか。 What is this in Japanese? A grammar particle which indicates the use of something for doing something.
docs.title: で

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 彼は日本語で話す でしょう 。 He will probably speak in Japanese. この本は高い だろう 。 This book is probably expensive. An auxiliary indicating conjecture grounded in no substantial evidence. だろう is the informal form.
docs.title: でしょう

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語 でも 話せます。 I can even speak Japanese. 子供 でも そのことをできます。 Even a child can do that. A particle meaning "even."
docs.title: でも

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 私はあなた と 日本語を勉強します。 I study Japanese with you. 私は日本人 と 結婚しました。 I (got) married ( to ) a Japanese person. A grammar particle indicating a reciprocal relationship with the subject.
docs.title: と

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語で どう 言いますか。 How do you say it in Japanese? 本は どう でしたか。 How was the book? A grammar particle which asks about the state of something or someone or the way of doing something.
docs.title: どう

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 この本はその本 と同じくらい 面白い。 This book is as interesting as that one. A phrase indicating that one thing is as 〜 as another.
docs.title: と同じくらい〜

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強する 時 本をたくさん読みます。 When I study Japanese I read a lot of books. 静かな 時 勉強できます。 I'm able to study when it's quiet. A dependent noun indicating a time when someone or something did or does something.
docs.title: とき

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語と英語と、 どちら が面白い？ Between Japanese and English, which is more interesting? A word meaning "which," among a group of things, particularly two.
docs.title: どちら

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 黄色と紫色と青色で、 どれ が一番美しいですか。 Between yellow, purple, and blue, which is the most beautiful? A word meaning "which," among a group of 3 or more.
docs.title: どれ

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 勉強し ないで 学校へ来ました。 I came to school without studying. A negative te-form indicating not doing something or without doing something.
docs.title: ないで

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 本を読み ながら 学校へ歩きました。 I walked to school while reading a book. A conjunction indicating the surrounding clauses happen simultaneously, often translated as "while" or "with."
docs.title: ながら

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 あなたの日本語が上手に なりました 。 You've become good at Japanese. 寒く なりました 。 It's become cold. A word meaning "to become" or "come to be."
docs.title: なる

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強（し） に 学校へ行きます。 I'm going to school (in order) to study Japanese. 本を買い に 来ました。 I came (in order) to buy a book. A particle indicating the purpose of movement. This construct is only used with motion verbs like 行く, 来る, 帰る, 入る, and 出る.
docs.title: に

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 本は日本語 の を買いました。 As for books, I bought a Japanese one . あの本はトム の です。 That book is Tom's book . 2 どうして勉強している の ？ Why are you studying ( you've got to tell me )? 明日テストがある の 。 Because there's a test tomorrow. 3 勉強する の は難しい。 Studying is difficult. 彼が日本語を話す の を聞きました。 I heard him speaking Japanese. A dependent, indefinite pronoun indicating "one" or "_'s." An informal sentence-final particle indicating an explanation or asking for an explanation, used by children or female speakers. If male speakers use it, it is only for questions. A clause nominalizer.
docs.title: の

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 何をしている んです か。 What are you doing ( you've got to tell me )? 日本語を勉強している のです 。 ( The explanation is that ) I'm studying Japanese. A sentence-ending phrase indicating an explanation or asking for an explanation. An informal form is んです.
docs.title: のです

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語 ばかり 勉強しています。 I'm studying only Japanese. 私は勉強した ばかり です。 I studied and haven't done anything else . A particle indicating that something is the only state, thing, or action.
docs.title: ばかり

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 あなたの本はどっちですか。 Which book is yours? 大きい ほう です。 The bigger one. 好きな ほう を取ってください。 Please take the one you like most . A word indicating more than or greater in a comparison. It comes from the form ほうが〜より.
docs.title: ほう

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語の ほうが 英語 より 面白い。 Japanese is more interesting than English. 遊ぶ ほうが 勉強する より 楽しい。 Playing is more fun than studying. A phrase for comparing two things, where one is more or greater than the other.
docs.title: ほうが〜より

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 英語は日本語 ほど 面白くない。 English is not as interesting as Japanese. A particle indicating an extent or degree, often translated as "[not] as ~ as ~."
docs.title: ほど

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 寝る 前に 日本語を勉強します。 I study Japanese before I sleep. テストの 前に 勉強します。 I'll study before the test. A conjunction indicating in front of or before something occurs.
docs.title: まえに (前に)

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 まだ 日本語を分かりません。 I still don't understand Japanese. 私は まだ 勉強しています。 I'm still studying. An adverb indicating that someone or something is still in a state they were previously in, often translated as "still" or "(not) yet."
docs.title: まだ

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し ましょう 。 Let's study Japanese. 日本語を勉強し ましょう か。 Shall we study Japanese? A formal volitional verb ending indicating the speaker's intent or invitation to do something.
docs.title: 〜ましょう

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し ませんか 。 Would you like to study Japanese? 2 一緒に勉強し ない？ Wanna study together? The formal negative question form of a verb can be used to extend an invitation formally. The informal non-past negative form of a verb can be used to extend an invitation informally.
docs.title: 〜ませんか

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は五時 まで 日本語を勉強します。 I will study Japanese until 5 o'clock. 東京 まで 3時間かかります。 It takes 3 hours until Tokyo. A grammar particle which indicates a spacial or temporal limit.
docs.title: まで

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 もう 日本語を勉強しましたか。 Have you already studied Japanese? もう 本がありません。 I don't have the book anymore . And adverb indicating that someone or something is no longer in a state they were previously in, often translated as "already" or "(not) any longer."
docs.title: もう

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 友達はこの本を買って もらいました 。 My friend bought me this book. 友達にこの本を もらいました 。 I received this book from my friend. An auxiliary verb indicating that the speaker or someone else receives something or some benefit from an action from someone else. The honorific form is いただく.
docs.title: もらう

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し よう 。 Let's study Japanese. 地球を守 ろう 。 Let's protect the Earth. An informal volition verb ending indicating the speaker's intent or invitation to do something.
docs.title: よう

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し ようと思います 。 I think I'll study Japanese. 英語で話す まいと思います 。 I think I won't speak in English. A phrase indicating that the speaker desires to do something. The negative form is まいと思う.
docs.title: ようとおもう (ようと思う)

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 漢字を読 める 。 I can read kanji. 刺身を食べ られます 。 I can eat sashimi. An auxiliary verb indicating the potential to do something.
docs.title: られる

docs.text: Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は日本語 を 勉強します。 I study Japanese. 2 私は公園 を 歩きました。 I walked through the park. A grammar particle indicating a direct object. A grammar particle indicating a space through or along which someone or something moves.
docs.title: を
